metadata.title: A Prospective Study of Respiratory Viral Infection in Pregnant Women With and Without Asthma

abstract.original_text: The majority (157/168, 93%) of the asthmatic women also commenced participation in the Managing Asthma in Pregnancy (MAP) study, which was a randomised controlled trial comparing clinical guideline-based management of asthma using symptoms and lung function, with the management of asthma guided by fractional exhaled nitric oxide (FENO) 1 . The primary results of the RCT in non-smoking women have been previously published, along with a secondary analysis 1,2 . 69 of the participants in this study were randomised to the FENO based management intervention of MAP, and 73 subjects to the clinical guidelines-based management intervention of the MAP RCT. 15 subjects commenced MAP but were not randomised. The remaining 11 subjects who did not participate in the RCT were not eligible because they were recruited prior to commencement of the MAP study (n=8), or did not wish to have their medications changed (n=2), or were excluded from the MAP study on the basis of exacerbation history (more than 3 courses of OCS in the past year, n=1)..

sentences.segment_text: The majority ( 157/168 , 93 % ) of the asthmatic women also commenced participation in the Managing Asthma in Pregnancy ( MAP ) study ,
which was a randomised controlled trial comparing clinical guideline-based management of asthma using symptoms and lung function ,
with the management of asthma guided by fractional exhaled nitric oxide ( FENO ) 1 .
The primary results of the RCT in non-smoking women have been previously published ,
69 of the participants in this study were randomised to the FENO based management intervention of MAP ,
and 73 subjects to the clinical guidelines-based management intervention of the MAP RCT .
15 subjects commenced MAP but were not randomised .
The remaining 11 subjects who did not participate in the RCT were not eligible because they were recruited prior to commencement of the MAP study ( n = 8 ) ,
or did not wish to have their medications changed ( n = 2 ) ,
or were excluded from the MAP study on the basis of exacerbation history ( more than 3 courses of OCS in the past year , n = 1 ) .
